instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.PPVCCIO_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCIO_S0_CPU? PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is a power rail responsible for powering the part of the CPU responsible for communicating with other portions of the machine prior to PPVCORE_S0_CPU being present and must be present before vcore, PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is present when the machine is in an on, RUNNING state. .
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..
definitions.PP1V8_S4: What is PP1V8_S4? PP1V8_S4 is a 1.8v power rail when the machine is in an S4, suspend to disk state. .
definitions.PP5_S4: What is PP5_S4? This is a typo of PP5V_S4 When you see PP5_S4, assume they meant to type PP5V_S4.
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Hello,

We have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that stoped working with no reason. It has no liquid damages or anything else... just stop working. The client reporta the following:

"For some time now, the computer disconnected almost all usb-c connections with the message that ?The USB accessory is consuming too much energy. The ports were turned off ?, which I imagine may have something to do with this event."

Here are the measurements I got:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH3V3</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S4_HS_TPAD</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S3_MEM_VREFD0_A</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S3_MEM_VREFCA_A</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S3_MEM_VREFD0_B</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> = Fluctuates between 1.4V and 0.5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3_MEM</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_SUS</SIGNAL> = Fluctuates between 0.6V and 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_S0SW</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_T139</SIGNAL> = Fluctuates between 0V and 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_T139</SIGNAL> = Fluctuates between 1V and 0.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = Fluctuates between 0V and 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_T151</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = Fluctuates between 0V and 0.5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = Fluctuates between 0V and 5V

The resistance of the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3M Ohm
The resistance of the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 5M Ohm

Can anyone help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Welcome to the forum!

I don't see any reason for such a big listing.
If you miss a SUS voltage, no S4 possible; of course no S3 and S0 too.
In fact, even S5 is not stable in your case.

Let as know exact 820-xxxx board code...

threads.message:
Please, maintain forum aestethic.
Do not comment; always better to write new post.

Check for stable level at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_PMICLDO</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V25_PMICVREF</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> and the 3 RTC signals (page 12).

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_PMICLDO</SIGNAL> = 3.29V stable
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_PMICVREF</SIGNAL> = 1.24V Stable
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3V Stable

Related to the RTC Sgnals, I don't have an oscilloscope. Is there any other way to diagnose?

No need of an o-scope.
I was refering to 3 DC signals, <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and see if you catch higger peak value on the fluctuating signals and voltages.

Also try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.message:

Related to start in SMC bypass mode, I don't know how to do it. Can you please explain it to me?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: I guess that you're talking about what I know as smc reset (10 seconds on power off button). If so, I already did it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
"Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>"
As you have to work with board alone on the desk, use SW5200, or <RESISTOR>R5226</RESISTOR> pads, instead of power button.
In fact, solder an wire on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and touch any metal plate (temporary contact), simulating power button.

"SMC bypass mode"
Put <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground, connect charger, maintain contact 5-10s; board should start when you release <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

Remember to work with board alone, nothing connected apart of charger (no battery).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: Thanks for the explanation 2informaticos. I?ve done SMC bypass mode, but with no sucess. Still no boot.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> repeatedly and check for reaction (pulse) at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL>; at same time as simulating power button.
First, be sure to get a drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

Check what happens trying to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
You should have a problem with SMC, or <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

Remove <RESISTOR>R8110</RESISTOR> and run a tiny wire from <CAPACITOR>C7653</CAPACITOR> to <CAPACITOR>C7644</CAPACITOR>.
Se if you get stable <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
If yes, try soldering <RESISTOR>R7663</RESISTOR>.

There is no <CAPACITOR>C7644</CAPACITOR> (no stuf) and the <CAPACITOR>C7653</CAPACITOR> is 3.298V. 
now, on  the pad of the R811, i have 3.4V on <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and 0V on <SIGNAL>PM_EM_PVXS5</SIGNAL>. 
Do you still want me to jumper both of them?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: It doesn´t fluctuate. It's 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message: Do you get correct <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> now?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
Hello,
No. We have 0V in both <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
On the ampmeter it is pulling only 4.97V and 0.13A

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not powering on
threads.message:
0.13A is high current in this conditions.
Do you get voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
Check LDO outputs of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips also.
